Tides are extremely important when considering a bar crossing, walk on the beach etc.  Tides always make   a difference of when you can SAFELY cross the bar.    Sometimes we have to wait until midnight, 2am. to  safely cross,   all based on how deep the water is at the bar.  Low depth at bar usually means you will have to wait a hour or two before you cross.  Other factors, swell direction, wind direction, time between swells, it all enters into when you can go.  Talk about tides.  Here in Oregon our CHANGEOVER,( the difference measured in feet between high and low tide),  is anywhere from a minus 2 feet to 9-10 feet.     On average its usually somewhere between 5-7 feet.  NOW,  up in Cook Inlet Alaska,  @ NINILCHIK,  the CHANGEOVER can be anywhere  from minus 2 feet to 40 feet.    This month of January there is around a 20 foot changeover.    HUGE, MONSTROUS, tide changeovers.  You do not see many people walking the beaches there as  the tides come in or go out horrifically fast.

Most work study jobs are students working as tutors or in college department offices.  Work study is awarded two ways need based and merit based.  Need based is because yours and your family income is below a certain level. Merit based because the job you have is helping you with your future career goals. Work study is helpful because many campus employers want to hire students with work study because the work study award pays part of the student's pay check - thus not out of the department's budget. We have students who work for us who do not want work study because it means they have less available they can borrow on student loans (poor decision in my opinion). It is still possible to get jobs without work study.  How many students work their way through school working at department stores, restaurants, convenience stores, or other on campus non-work study jobs?  Quite a few and they can still do so.

The suburbs are better than they used to be in most cities, with entertainment and dining options that simply didn't exist in the 70s outside of fast food and the odd mini-putt or bowling alley.  But to my way of thinking, unless they are well served by transit and in an established neighbourhood, the tradeoffs are mighty high.  Savings are illusory; the costs of transportation and lost time in commutes quickly eat up the delta in purchase price in many cities.

And if the good Professor's wish comes true -- an end to free parking and the addition of toll roads -- the suburban dream will quickly become an expensive nightmare.  In a neighbourhood with a walk score of less than,say, 60, it is all but impossible to live without a private car, and if motorists are gouged every time they turn the key, the allure of a back yard and two car parking will quickly evaporate.

Sorry, but while you may think a renewal at the same institution is very different from a "refinancing" elsewhere, legally, not so much.  Your original lender is under NO obligation to "renew" you, despite what people believe.  When your term ends, you need somebody, somewhere to lend you the amount owing at that time, and if you don't like the conditions and rates offered, tough...   It is true that the measure, as now written, creates a significant bias to remaining with the original lender - but why should that only benefit the banks? It also means the credit unions, and any other lending firm, have an advantage in retaining their own loans.  The rules should just apply all over, period, but the government is dancing around trying to cool things without an outright crash.  But a crash is the only way to fix the market, and get back to prices at 3-4, or at most 5 times income.

The State uses a formula to calculate need.  Local districts in all organized areas must contribute a percentage of that number to get their state funding, but they also have a cap beyond which they can contribute no more.
If the State lowers the BSA, as they are suggesting, it will lower how much the Muni can contribute to ASD, as Anchorage has always contributed at the cap.
There are other appropriations by the state outside of this, so it does get complicated, but the reduction the State is considering will cause a cut in local funds as well.
That's one reason a lot of us do favor an income tax.  There are people in unorganized areas that have a nice W-2 that contribute nothing to their local schools, or police protection or any other state service.

HI:Had the same reading experience!!My dad went over in mid 43 and was there through some of the resettlement in latter part of 45.
He was in the REME corps.
His letters written to my mom were done to help ease the pain of distance and the scary unknown. I read a few but I felt I was intruding on their private lives(both passed a decade ago)with one having a lock of my moms hair in the envelope.
I have a small box with at least a 100 communicates back and forth that my mom kept from the war.
Our son went and saw Dunkirk(the movie) and before he went he asked about his granddad and the war so I read a few of the letters and sent him a scan of a post card my dad sent from Holland saying "Somewhere In Holland ,going across to Germany,going out to check a bridge head with infantry.Love"
My mom said death notices were sent by telegram to the door so no one wanted a telegram(or to open one).
I can't believe how strong my parents marriage was.

The Courts have strictly rejected any changes that would violate contracts, and everyone has to agree that the principle is essential to a law-governed society. By law, employers who entered into contracts with their employees must pay the promised PERS payments. Measure 97 revenues are restricted by law to "public education (early childhood through grade 12); healthcare; services for senior citizens." There is a choice about whether we are going to fund our schools.

Have the higher income spouse pay all household expenses, including any taxes payable by the lower income spouse to maximize the investment income earning assets of the low income spouse where they pay less tax.

Make contributions to a spousal RRSP with the low income spouse as the annuitant. The high income spouse deducts the RRSP contribution and after 3 years the low income spouse can pull the money out and pay little or no tax on it.

Living in a cold climate is no boon for any type of car and both gas and electric cars have their own problems. Ice in fuel lines is not a problem with electric cars.

Just want to correct a few things in the article. There were actually many kind neighbors who supported our event. The property next door gave us as emergency water hose from their house down to our event just in case the 2 water trucks containing 6,000 gallons of water needed back up. We had 12 fire extinguishers throughout the site, 300 gallons of water in buckets all around the site for close proximity. Another neighbor down the street loaned us his house all weekend so staff could shower any time (we are a tiny staff and worked from 6am - 12am every day!) Many more neighbors came by to offer words of praise & asked how they could help. The event goers were all gone from the site by 12pm Sunday and we cleaned up through Sunday night and left after the eclipse. We definitely bought the stores out of ice and other last minute items. First , they must determine if he can aid in his own defense at the time of trial -- if he is competent to stand trial.   What happened at the time of the offense is a WHOLE other matter under the law.   If he is able to be "restored" to be able to stand trial, then they will deal with the issue of his mental state at the time of the incident.   That is the law.   If he has a severe mental disease or defect, he MIGHT, in OREGON be able to be deemed Guilty Except for Insanity (GEI) which will get him treatment (as you suggest).   Please see:  http://www.oregon.gov/prb/Pages/GEI-Adults.aspx      

He would then be subject to the Psychiatric Security Review Board (PSRB) until they see fit to release him (if ever).   
None of this can take place until he can help in his own defense (if that ever happens) and if he cannot ever do that, he will go directly to the PSRB.  This is what happened with Cheryl Kidd, the person who killed Officer Chris Kilcullen. 
Hope this helps.

The article says adjacent farmers complain about noxious weeds on the 2000 acre (~3 square miles) farm. Noxious weed is a legal term describing weeds that are poisonous to livestock or humans, like tansy ragwort, st. john's wort, water hemlock, English yew, English laurel, English ivy, holly, and many more. Not to say they aren't beautiful creations, just that they are toxic. Many more are tremendously invasive to the point of destroying land for cultivation, pasturage, or retail, like the various knotweeds. If you had children or livestock around, you would want to eliminate them, including the very poisonous digitalis, or foxglove, and you certainly wouldn't want your little kids to eat sweet peas, let alone the seeds of beautiful lupines. All of these are God's creations, but didn't God put man in charge of it all?

Even for atheists, those are undesirable plants to have in your garden. It would be interesting to know which plants the neighbors object to. That's my only point.

Well, you're right about that: they do just want to finish the case and move on.  If you saw their dockets, you'd understand why.

You're also right that appellate judges do rely heavily on their clerks, like doctors rely on nurses and airline pilots on their first officers.  But the idea that clerks decide cases is foolish.  There are five justices on the Supreme Court and three judges on the Court of Appeals.  Unless there is a recusal (rare), all of these judges, and their clerks, consider every case.  They disagree often--i.e., they check each other's work.  That doesn't mean every case gets oral argument--especially at the Court of Appeals, where a great many appeals are essentially pro forma and can be decided on the briefs.  Are bad decisions?  Of course.  But (unless you're a Trumpobot) that doesn't mean the system is rigged.  It means that any human institution is fallible.  In every case, somebody is going to lose.  That means unhapiness and criticism.  Such is life.

Exchange Income Corp reports non-IFRS compliant "free cash flow" to show a reasonable payout ratio. However, every company must funds its growth capex, partially from its retained cash flow (equity) and new debt, assuming they keep their debt/equity ratios flat. With this as a background, payout ratios are higher than 100%. To make things worse, company considers reduction in working capital as a "sustainable" source of cash to fund distributions. A growing company doesn't reduce its working capital and fund distributions. Current distributions are not sustainable -company is  issuing equity from time to time, raising debt levels to fund its growth plans and maintaining high distributions.

I think that opening up financial advisors to undue litigation is a good rationale for dialing back the law. But reading up on it makes it less of a good reason. Investment advisors have been held to this rule already, but the new law expanded the group that must follow the law to include advisors that don't charge an hourly fee for their client interaction. This is mostly because financial advisors have moved to other business models. So it seems to be mostly responding to a change in business practices rather than fundamentally changing how exposed advisors are to litigation. The law itself is more detailed about what advisors must do, for example they have to disclose commissions on financial products. So it is more about transparency than vague "I'm going to sue because that stock tanked".

There is no doubt that a large and sustained rise in interest rates would cause problems. The problems would occur as people renew their mortgages. The impacts on those people will depend on multiple factors, including how much does their monthly payment increase and what has happened to their income and their other costs of living since they got the mortgage (and how much of the mortgage principal have they repaid, through their regular payments and any bonus payments). Obviously.we don't know in advance what will happen to these factors. We have seen in the past that when people face payment increases that they can't afford, the pressures can be relieved by adjusting their payment - extending their amortization period. So long as people have jobs, mortgage problems can be solved most of the time. The most critical issue is what is the state of the economy - do people have jobs?

It helps if the writer was completely informed about the topic, rather than implying something nefarious by the lack of charges against people crossing the border illegally. All the arm-chair quarterbacks online need to inform themselves as well.

When a person crosses the border by eluding an examination at an official port of entry, they are breaching  the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. That results in two possible legal consequences. The person will be dealt with solely under the immigration rules of that law, or charged with a criminal offence under section 124. However, if they seek protection, s. 133 of the law states the person cannot be charged with a criminal offence related to their entry until their protection claim is determined. Practically, if a person doesn't get protection they are removed from Canada, rather than spending more resources on courts and imprisonment. The RCMP and CBSA are acting according to law. There is nothing political in their actions.

Common sense demands careful deliberation. You've reached your amounts through extreme simplification, and basic arithmetic requires all the variables.

The current safety net is super expensive to operate, which leads to a lower return on the investment in the economy. The City agreed that there would be no annexation until full city services were available. The owners paid LC tax rate for first few years...at around year 5, with still no sewer installed, notice of annexation was received and tax bills doubled and tripled. A tangled mess. Sewer eventually installed but City refused to credit owners with the years of paying annexed tax rate (thousands of dollars for each homeowner) with no city sewer. Attorney stated the owners had a case but the City would use strategy to keep it in court and be too costly for the homeowners to challenge. Businesses treated differently? Maybe but.....

Logic dictates that the non-violent actions of a single man could never change the course of history for several hundred million Indians and 50 million Brits. Monuments, once designated, can only be un-designated by Congress. FDR wanted to undo the Castle  Pinckney Monument in South Carolina in 1938, but was told by his Office of Legal Counsel that he had no authority to undo the monument, that only Congress could revoke the  monument designation(Which it eventually did, in 1956). Bush 43 was told the same thing after reviewing some of Clinton's midnight monuments upon taking office in 2001. So Bush left the monuments alone, and eventually added 6 monuments of his own. monument designations are a very special kind of executive order, the kind that are-unless Congress acts- permanent. Trump can undo a lot of Obama's moves. Monuments however, aren't one of them. Any monuments Obama creates in AK, regardless of number or size, will be upheld by the courts, due to Supreme Court precedent. Congress will gripe and grumble about it, but eventually will appropriate money for the monuments as part of the appropriations process.

Stone Mountain Confederate Memorial was originally privately owned as a granite quarry. The Daughters of the Confederacy conceived the carved mural of Davis, Lee and Stonewall Jackson, and hired the same person who later completed Mount Rushmore, after quitting the Confederate project. The site at Stone Mountain was the location of the beginning of the 2nd KKK in 1915, so it has some history in Jim Crow. Stone Mountain was bought by the State of Georgia and the sculpture was finished using private donations. No doubt it is Holy Mecca to a certain type of nostalgia pilgrim. I can't see Georgia blowing it up any time soon, but you know, Atlanta is becoming increasingly liberal. On the other hand, I would guess that it generates revenue.

Any time Pope Francis talks with reporters on the papal plane, you know something interesting is about to happen. This time was no exception.

What strikes me about his comments isn't that he said anything new (he mostly reiterated traditional Catholic teaching on gender identity), but that he resisted making a blanket condemnation or speaking negatively about transgender people. Instead, he went where he usually does, encouraging personal dialogue, pastoral sensitivity and taking each situation as it comes.

I can't help but contrast that with the knee-jerk way many U.S. bishops have dealt with the issue. I wish they'd take a page from Francis' book and let their default mode be one of conversation rather than edict. It could only improve their low stock with U.S. Catholics.

One minor quibble about the headline. The pope never said that morality is determined case-by-case, which is not only misleading but bad theology. How 'bout we lighten up on the 'click-bait' headlines?

A few points.  
1.  Typically sales, excise and use taxes are based on transaction or market values. Nice article Dave.  Catch and release has always appealed to me as a way to make sure my kids and grandkids get a chance to fish as well.  As I age I do less fishing overall, and I admit having more sympathy for the fish.  I'm am extremely careful about crushing the barb, and I never use light gear anymore.  Many more fish get away just before landing, which is great because I never have to handle them.  Those that I do land are much fresher, requiring little to no revival before darting back to their haunt.

Releasing a maimed fish defeats the purpose of preserving the resource.  A few of my pet peeves: 1.  Treble hooks are for harvesting (crimping the barbs doesn't change the equation much).   2. Choose a hook length that minimizes eye damage.  3. Grabbing the hook with a pair of pliers and shaking is a terrible technique.  The fish needs his jaw intact.

There used to be a Greater Anchorage Area Borough and a City of Anchorage (the Borough was the equivalent of a county).  In 1975 the city of Anchorage and the GAAB merged to form the Municipality of Anchorage.  After the merger, some services were available Municipality wide, while others (such as police, fire and road maintenance services) were put is special tax districts, so if you live in an area that pays the tax assessment, you get the service, and if you don't live in an area that pays, you don't get the service.  The property tax rates in places without services (such as police) have a lower mill rate than places with the services, which pay a higher rate.

A case in point. WA neighbor, the state of Idaho already has a history of selling its public lands. Nearly one third of the lands given to Idaho at statehood have been sold, resulting in back country skiers, hikers, hunters, and fishermen losing access to more than a million acres. Some of these lands have ended up being used for private hunting/fishing preserves for wealthy out of state visitors.

Now many have blamed former President Obama, BLM, and the EPA for blocking public usage (typically targeting energy extraction, grazing rights and mining) of federally managed public lands by extending and establishing National Monuments. However if states take-over the management of US public lands, the access situation would get much worse. Though Rep. Ryan Zinke has actively opposed many such transfers, it remains to be seen if the presumed new Interior Secretary can stop the GOP-backed plan to transfer federal public lands to the states essentially for free. We will need to watch this.

Spencer wrote  in his Principles of Biology, "This survival of the fittest, which I have here sought to express in mechanical terms, is that which Mr. Darwin has called 'natural selection', or the preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life." Darwin liked the phrase, as did  Alfred Russel Wallace, who had developed the theory of natural selection independently of Darwin (but Darwin published first -- after being made aware of Wallace's work). Darwin himself used it in some of the later editions of Origin of Species, meaning "better designed for an immediate, local environment".

Unfortunately, Spencer and some of his followers took the phrase in what they called a moral sense,  as an ethical precept that sanctioned cut-throat economic competition. Some of the more extreme Social Darwinists said that the poor should not be helped, since it would be aiding the "less fit" in surviving. They claimed that social caste was determined by natural superiority.

I will admit that this is easier to understand in terms of unity of teaching with variety in application, but we are a sacramental church, so unity of practice should be doable. I'm not sure I am up to it, but maybe somebody is.
Take the Eucharist. For 1500+ years it was explained in terms of pre-Christian religious ritual, like sacrifice and altars. The final stage in a sacrifice is the sharing of the victim to enable a distribution of the numinous among the believers.
The same ritual can be reinterpreted from a different perspective. Instead of the sacrifice as explanatory key, the meal can be understood as Christ's purpose. Christ died so that we can share in his life. The concluding communal meal is a more effective key today than the rarely experienced ritual sacrifice, in a Church based on communion.

there hasn't been any attention to the wasp population or feeding patterns yet, but a lot of us think that their population boost was related to both the warm weather as well as the large number of aphids and soft-body defoliators (caterpillars, etc).  The wasps feed soft bodied insects like aphids and caterpillars to their young, and the higher temperatures are beneficial to the metabolic rate of cold blooded organisms (wasps can grow and mature faster when it is warmer, so they can afford to produce more young).  
The progress of the spruce aphids over the past century has been pretty interesting in the abstract:  They first came to North America from Europe in the early 1900's, and have slowly made their way west and north, with their northward expansion following warming trends rather closely.  The good thing about their ecology is that they require cool and moist conditions like those prevalent in Southeast, and on the Sitka Spruce-dominated coastline.  (cont'd)

Around about 1909, there were two rivers flowing out of the Rockies. One headed north into Canada. The other headed north into Canada and then south back into the U.S.

The Americans decided "their" river wasn't as good as the one that flowed into Canada and stayed there. So they decided to dig a canal to take some of the water out and put it into their river. People in Alberta heard about this and decided to dig their own canal between the two rivers. They promised, whatever water the Americans diverted from the first river would be diverted right back in once the river flowed into Canada. The Albertans referred to it as the "S;pite Canal". 

So if the U.S. wants to put tariffs on any cars that come into the U.S. where they decide the plant was 'relocated' from the U.S., Canada should do exactly the same thing for vehicles coming in from the U.S. where the plant was "relocated" from Canada.

"There is no ‚Äúblank page‚Äù to stare you down; there is a series of notes to follow. An outline is a far more powerful motivator than a timer."

Established authors do a disservice to beginners when they tell them they must outline.  I never could.  If I'd believed what Mr Smith says, I might have quit before I really got started.

I start with a character in his/her normal situation then create an event that propels that character into a conflict.  Then I see how it works out.  I'm often halfway or even two-thirds the way through a novel before I know how it's going to end.

And it doesn't take me a year to write one.  At a thousand words a day, working most days, I can produce a novel in four months -- and that includes revisions and polishing.  I've sold nineteen novels, to publishers large and small, and ghosted three more for other people, to be published under their names.

I'm not rich and famous, but George R.R. Martin did call one of my books "a tremendous amount of fun."

Religious liberties are not absolute.   If consciences are to be burdened by a generally applicable federal law that advances a compelling government interest, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act requires that this be done in the least restrictive way possible. It's not sufficient to maintain that such a burden only amounts to a remote material cooperation (e.g. opt-out accommodation); it's necessary to establish that no other way would be as practicable & effective. 

The question thus turns on the government showing that alternate distribution channels are infeasible. Since the Affordable Care Act model revolves around employment-based health insurance, the goverment has argued that requiring other distribution alternatives would upend that model, which the law, itself, presupposed as the most feasible means. That presupposition was already well founded & well grounded, as that model's feasibility had been empirically established and long-practiced. 

The need must be met somehow!

An excellent article, however missing the fact that models are already working elsewhere in the world that clearly show 1) government shouldn't be involved in Transport, and 2) Transport is a total revenue opportunity for government, not an 'obligation' or 'expense line'.
City of Toronto's (not the GTA!) and Hong Kong's population density are actually similar. Toronto has half the population and area of Hong Kong. Hong Kong loses US$1 billion annually operating its public transit. Sounds familiar. But Hong Kong's Metrolinks equivalent, the MTR Corp, has *net* US$2 billion profit, of which HK Gov't gets US$1.5 billion in dividends (it owns of 75% of MTR Corps shares - the rest trade on the stock market). So HK has *no* transport costs and US$1.5 billion to boot. Plus corporate taxes too. 
You can't always get a profit, but you can always reduce the costs. Corporations are 1,000x better at this than governments and should be let lose to save cities from their politicians and budget woes.

I retired from teaching in 2014 and there was a marked change in kids' fixation on computer games during my final 5 - 10 years. At recess and lunch-hour, a dominant topic among the kids was their games: Minecraft, Grand Theft Auto, various motorcycle-riding simulators, etc.
As students headed for the bus at the end of the day they would discuss what level they were at, what level they hoped to achieve that evening, who they'd be playing with, etc.

Others were into rap videos, even whispers of porn sites, perhaps even worse.

Parents complained that they couldn't get their kid in bed... they'd catch him playing at midnight, then he'd refuse to get up & go to school. 

Students who misbehaved openly said, "Good... send me home. I'd much rather play ___ than be in school."

I think the ballooning obesity rate is due more to screen time than it is to diet. Some kids would rather play than eat...much less socialize in the real world.
